title: Designing a Predictive Risk Model for High-Value Assets
text:
This project demonstrates an end‑to‑end approach to designing, validating, and evaluating a predictive risk model in a pricing context. The focus is on modelling judgement, feature design, and validation rather than maximising headline performance metrics.
All data used in this project is fully synthetic and does not reflect any proprietary datasets.

title: Designing a Predictive Risk Model for High-Value Assets
text:
Problem Statement
We consider a hypothetical insurance‑style problem where the goal is to predict the probability of a high‑cost loss event for individual policies, based on customer, asset, and contextual features.
Key challenges include: - Class imbalance - Feature leakage - Model interpretability vs performance trade‑offs

title: Designing a Predictive Risk Model for High-Value Assets
text:
Data Generation
We generate a synthetic dataset designed to capture common characteristics of real‑world consumer risk portfolios: - Skewed loss distribution - Correlated features - Rare but severe outcomes

title: Designing a Predictive Risk Model for High-Value Assets
text:
Data Generation
import numpy as np import pandas as pd
np.random.seed(42)
n = 20000
data = pd.DataFrame({ “vehicle_value”: np.random.lognormal(mean=10, sigma=0.5, size=n), “driver_age”: np.random.randint(18, 80, size=n), “annual_mileage”: np.random.gamma(shape=2, scale=6000, size=n), “urban_density”: np.random.beta(2, 5, size=n), “prior_claims”: np.random.poisson(0.3, size=n) })
logit = ( -7.0 + 0.000002 * data[“vehicle_value”] - 0.015 * data[“driver_age”] + 0.00004 * data[“annual_mileage”] + 1.5 * data[“urban_density”] + 0.6 * data[“prior_claims”] )
prob = 1 / (1 + np.exp(-logit)) data[“high_cost_claim”] = np.random.binomial(1, prob)
data.head()
